newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Santos portworkers ask for partial cut in hours.
newsitem.headline: Santos portworkers ask for partial cut in hours.

text.p: Portworkers at Brazil's key port of Santos have asked port authority CODESP to reduce working hours in some areas of the port during 60 days to allow them to adjust to 24-hour operations, CODESP said.

The period would allow for adjustments in infra-structure, such as preparing quays for continuous working and arranging around-the-clock transport for officials, CODESP said in a statement published after a meeting of portworkers Tuesday.

The statement did not mention a possible national strike by portworkers, due to have been discussed at the meeting. No union officials were immediately available to confirm if the strike over wages, tentatively scheduled for July 14, will go ahead.

A spokeswoman for CODESP said she wasn't aware of any fresh strike plans but added that Santos portworkers, who held a two-day strike last week, had rejected a CODESP proposal to extend their existing collective wage agreement by six months.
"They want a new wage agreement," she said.
It was not clear if the Santos portworkers planned any fresh stoppages, she added.
CODESP said it would study all proposals related to the port's transition to 24-hour operations, due to have begun June 30 but delayed by last week's labor dispute.
